name: hArduino
tagline: Control your Arduino board from Haskell
body:
hArduino
==========

[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/LeventErkok/hArduino.png)](http://travis-ci.org/LeventErkok/hArduino)

hArduino allows Haskell programs to control [Arduino](http://arduino.cc/) boards and peripherals, using the [Firmata](http://firmata.org) protocol.

**Important Note:** The Firmata project has moved on since hArduino was released, and their latest protocol implementation does not work with hArduino. Please use the following (slightly older) copy for hArduino: [Standard Firmata](http://github.com/LeventErkok/hArduino/blob/master/StandardFirmata/StandardFirmata.ino). See also instructions below.

On Hackage (v1.0): [hArduino](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hArduino). (Released: March 27, 2016.)

Some example programs:

   * Hello world: The standard led-blinking example: [Blink.hs]
(http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Blink.html)
   * Morse code: Transmit morse-code messages by blinks: [Morse.hs] (http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Morse.html)
   * Controlling a digital switch: [Button.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Button.html)
   * Implementing a counter via a pair of push-buttons: [Counter.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Counter.html)
   * Reading an analog input value: [Analog.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Analog.html)
   * Control an LCD display: [LCD.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-LCD.html)
   * Number guessing game using OSEPP shield: [NumGuess.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-NumGuess.html)
   * Sending and receiving pulses: [Pulse.hs]
(http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Pulse.html)
   * Measure distance using HC-SR04: [Distance.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Distance.html)
   * Play jingle-bells on a Piezo speaker: [JingleBells.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-JingleBells.html)
   * Control a 7-segment-display: [SevenSegment.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-SevenSegment.html)
   * Control a servo motor: [Servo.hs](http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hArduino/latest/doc/html/System-Hardware-Arduino-SamplePrograms-Servo.html)
  
`NB.` Sample programs above use the device `/dev/cu.usbmodemfd131` to access the Arduino, which happens to be the port I use on my development Mac machine. Make sure you use the correct port name in the call to the `withArduino` function, pointing to the USB port your Arduino is connected to. (On Linux, this will look like one of `/dev/ttyUSB*`, `/dev/ttyACM*` or similar. On Windows, it will look something like `COM3`.)

There is a short [video](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPa3im44t2g) (4m29s) demonstrating the blink example.

hArduino has been tested on Mac OSX (Mountain Lion), Linux (Ubuntu 12.04.2), and Windows 7. Patches, bug reports, and suggestions are most welcome.

[Release notes](http://github.com/LeventErkok/hArduino/blob/master/CHANGES.md).

## Arduino setup

NB. Unfortunately hArduino does **not** work with latest releases of the firmata protocol as it is maintained by the Arduino community. This is not unexpected: Firmata moves on, but there isn't enough resources to keep all the clients up-to-date with the latest versions. To use hArduino, you need to make sure your Arduino board is connected to your computer, and a custom version of the firmata protocol is running on it: 

  * Install the Arduino environment: http://arduino.cc/en/Main/Software.
  * Start the Arduino IDE. Get a copy of the Firmata protocol file, found here: [Firmata Protocol](http://github.com/LeventErkok/hArduino/blob/master/StandardFirmata/StandardFirmata.ino). Load it in the Arduino IDE, and upload it to your board. (Note: Do **NOT** use the File->Examples->Firmata menu option to find StandardFirmata; use the custom version to get the version of Firmata that is known to work with HArduino!)
  * [Optional] Run the  [firmata_test](http://firmata.org/wiki/Main_Page#Firmata_Test_Program) program to ensure your computer can access the Arduino via Firmata.
  * Quit the Arduino IDE. You don't need it running for hArduino to work.

Note that you need to do these steps only **once**. Once you get StandardFirmata running on your board, it will stay there even if you disconnect your Arduino from the USB port, or completely power down your computer.
